facts.text: Petition No. 110 of 1959 filed under Original Jurisdiction as Writ Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 110 of 1959. Writ Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 7, 1960 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March, 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-The petitioner is a companyoperative society duly registered

facts.text: Petitioner is a co-operative society duly registered and carries on business of plying motor buses as stage carriages on public highways in State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a companyoperative society duly registered and it carries on the business of plying motor buses as stage carriages on the public highways in the State of Bombay. Its case in this

facts.text: Petitioner deprived of right to carry on business and subjected to discriminatory treatment in grant of permits.

anchor.surface_text: Its case in this petition is that it has been deprived of its right to carry on this business and has also been subjected to discriminatory treatment in the matter of the grant of permits

facts.text: Petitioner had permits to run buses on four routes in Aurangabad due to expire on October 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the petitioner had permits to run buses on four routes in Aurangabad and that these permits were due to expire on October 1, 1958. The third respondent who really represents

facts.text: State of Bombay had permits for two of the four routes.

anchor.surface_text: The third respondent who really represents the Government of the State of Bombay and who may be companyveniently referred to as the State of Bombay, had permits for two of these routes.

facts.text: State of Bombay applied for permits for all four routes under Chapter IV on May 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On May 19, 1958, the State of Bombay applied for permits for all these four routes under Chapter IV of the Act. On May 27, 1958, the petitioner applied for renewal of its existing permits.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for renewal of its existing permits on May 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1958, the petitioner applied for renewal of its existing permits. The first respondent rejected the application of the petitioner and granted those of the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority (respondent 1) rejected petitioner's application and granted State's applications.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent rejected the application of the petitioner and granted those of the State of Bombay. The petitioner appealed to the second respondent but its appeal was rejected.

facts.text: Petitioner's appeal to State Transport Authority (respondent 2) was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner appealed to the second respondent but its appeal was rejected. In the meantime on some date which does number appear on the record, the petitioner had been granted

facts.text: Petitioner granted temporary permits up to December 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime on some date which does number appear on the record, the petitioner had been granted temporary permits up to December 31, 1958. On the expire of its temporary permits

facts.text: Bombay High Court under Art 226 quashed orders of respondents 1 and 2 and directed reconsideration of applications.

anchor.surface_text: On the expire of its temporary permits on December 31, 1958, the petitioner would have been unable to run any of its buses and it therefore moved the High Court at Bombay under art. 226

facts.text: Respondent 1 granted temporary permits to State of Bombay without reconsidering as directed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, however, without reconsidering the applications as directed by the High Court, granted temporary permits to the State of Bombay. The petitioner again moved the High Court

facts.text: Bombay High Court quashed respondent 1's order granting temporary permits to State.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner again moved the High Court which thereupon quashed the order of respondent No. 1 granting temporary permits to the State of Bombay. Thereafter, on March 20, 1959, the

facts.text: Respondent 1 granted temporary permits to petitioner on March 20, 1959, later extended to July 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on March 20, 1959, the respondent No. 1 granted temporary permits to the petitioner which were later extended to July 20, 1959. On June 1, 1959, the State of Bombay published

facts.text: State of Bombay published scheme under s. 68C on June 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On June 1, 1959, the State of Bombay published a scheme under s. 68C in Chapter IVA of the Act. Various objections were filed against the scheme and numberhing further appears to

facts.text: Various objections filed against the scheme under s. 68C, nothing further done to finalize it.

anchor.surface_text: Various objections were filed against the scheme and numberhing further appears to have been done to make the scheme final.

facts.text: On July 18, 1959, respondent 1 reconsidered applications, rejected petitioner's, allowed State's.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1959, respondent No. 1 purporting to carry out the directions of the High Court, reconsidered the petitioners applications for renewal and the applications of the State of Bombay

facts.text: Petitioner's temporary permits expired on July 20, 1959, and it ceased to operate buses.

anchor.surface_text: On July, 20, 1959, the petitioners temporary permits having expired, it ceased to operate its buses. On August 27, 1959, the petitioner filed the present petition in this Court

facts.text: Petitioner filed present petition under Art 32 on August 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On August 27, 1959, the petitioner filed the present petition in this Court under art. 32 of the Constitution for appropriate writs quashing the order of respondent No. 1 dated July 18,

facts.text: Respondents are: 1. Regional Transport Authority Aurangabad, 2. State Transport Authority Bombay, 3. Divisional Controller State Transport Marathwada, 4. State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to this petition are  1  The Regional Transport Authority, Aurangabad,  2  The State Transport Authority, Bombay,  3  The Divisional Controller of State Transport, Marathwada and  4  The State.

facts.text: Aurangabad and Marathwada are both in State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Aurangabad and Maratliwada are both in the State of Bombay. The first and second respondents are the authorities set up under s. 44 of the Act by the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner contends State had no right to apply for permits under Chapter IV due to Chapter IVA.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner first companytends that in view of chapter IV-A the State of Bombay bad numberright to apply for permits under Chapter IV of the Act as it had done.

facts.text: Court holds State entitled to apply for permits under Chapter IV.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that the petitioners companytention that the Government cannot apply for a permit under Chapter IV of the Act is unsustainable.

It companyplains of the infringement of its fundamental rights under arts. 19 1 g and 14 of the Constitution. The questions raised in this matter turn on some of the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, as amended by Act 100 of 1956. These provisions have to be examined before proceeding to discuss the questions that arise.

issues.text: whether the State of Bombay was entitled to apply for permits under Chapter IV

anchor.surface_text: The first question then is whether the State of Bombay was entitled to apply for permits under Chapter IV. The petitioner says that special provisions having been made in Chapter IVA to enable the Government to run its buses the Governments right to run buses was restricted to those provisions and the Government was not entitled to resort to the other provisions of the Act.

issues.text: whether any fundamental right of the petitioner under art. 19(1)(g) would have been affected by the Government having applied for and obtained permits under Chapter IV without having the right to do so
whether the petitioner was entitled to preference over the Government under the proviso to s.47(1) and whether the respondent No.1's decision not granting such preference infringes Art.14
whether if Chapter IV permits the State to compete with a private citizen, it offends Art.14 because in view of the vast resources of the State a private citizen is bound to lose in such competition
whether the order of the first respondent granting permits to the State of Bombay under Chapter IV was illegal affecting fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(g)

holdings.text: The petitioners contention that the Government cannot apply for a permit under Chapter IV of the Act is unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that the petitioners contention that the Government cannot apply for a permit under Chapter IV of the Act is unsustainable. The petitioner cannot complain of the Government having applied under that Chapter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter IV and IVA provide independent powers for government to obtain permits; s.42(3)(a) plainly requires permits for commercial government vehicles; rejects Nazir Ahmad principle, expressio unius, and purposive arguments limiting to IVA.

holdings.text: No fundamental right of the petitioner under art. 19(1)(g) affected by the Government having applied for and obtained permits under Chapter IV.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Since government entitled to apply under Chapter IV, no illegal action or infringement occurs.

holdings.text: The proviso to s.47(1) does not entitle the petitioner co-operative society to preference over the Government, and respondent No.1's decision does not offend Art.14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso prefers co-operatives over individual owners only; does not exclude or subordinate government applicants; RTA acts quasi-judicially with appeal remedies available, no direct Art.14 breach.

holdings.text: Chapter IV permitting the State to compete with private citizens for permits does not offend Art.14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.19(6) expressly authorizes State to carry on business partially or completely in competition with citizens without violating equality.

holdings.text: Post-1956 amendment, s.42(3)(a) requires State Government to obtain permits for transport vehicles used in commercial enterprise.

anchor.surface_text: The new cl.(a) provides that sub-sec.(1) shall not apply to any transport vehicle owned by the Central Government or a State Government and used for Government purposes unconnected with any commercial enterprise. Since the amendment, therefore, the Government cannot run stage carriages on the public highways without a permit, just as a private owner of stage carriages cannot do...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment removed prior exemption for government commercial vehicles, placing them on same footing as private owners under s.42(1).

holdings.text: Under Chapter IVA, post-approved scheme, State transport undertaking entitled to permits as matter of right under s.68F(1).

anchor.surface_text: When the Government chooses to proceed under that chapter, it becomes entitled as a matter of right under s.68F(1) to the necessary permits. Under Chapter IV the Government does not have any such advantage it has to compete with other applicants...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68F(1) mandates issuance of permits to State undertaking notwithstanding Chapter IV, distinguishing from competitive process under Chapter IV.

anchor.surface_text: His point is that Chapter IVA was introduced by the amendment of 1956 to meet the observations made in Moti Lal v. Government of Uttar Pradesh 2   and some other cases that s. 42 3  a  was discriminatory in that it exempted the Government from the requirement of a permit and was hence void as offending art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was then drawn to the proviso to s. 47 1 under which other thing, being equal a companyperative society is entitled to preference over individual owners in the matter of grants of permits. It is said that the Government is number an individual owner and therefore it is number companytemplated as an applicant for a permit under s. 47. It seems to us that if the Government is number an individual owner-as to which we are number called upon to say anything-it does number follow that section does number companytemplate the Government as an applicant for permit.
